headline.main: Comfortably on Earth, Astronaut Escapes a Jam

results.snippet: Apart from the winners of the major championships at the Spring Nationals in Houston last month, the top news story was about Col. Gregory H. Johnson.
results.lead_paragraph: Apart from the winners of the major championships at the Spring Nationals in Houston last month, the top news story was about Col. Gregory H. Johnson. He was born in England but is a NASA astronaut who was the pilot of the STS-123 Endeavour shuttle trip to the International Space Station in March 2008. A keen bridge player, he took a spade ace with him for the 6.6-million-mile voyage. (NASA permits astronauts only 10 personal items, and a deck is considered to be 52.) At the Houston event Johnson presented the card and a certificate of authenticity to Jay Baum, the chief executive of the American Contract Bridge League, and Jerry Fleming, this year's league president.

headline.main: Out of Orbit, Astronaut Meets His Chess Foes

results.snippet: Six months and 21 moves into the game, an astronaut met his opponents: elementary school students from Bellevue, Wash.
results.lead_paragraph: Last September, Gregory E. Chamitoff was working 12 to 16 hour days but still found time for one of his favorite hobbies: chess. Usually, his opponents were coworkers, but he also started a long-distance correspondence game against some players in Washington State. He did not know them personally, but they quickly became friends, even talking to each other via video hook-ups over the Internet.

headline.main: Astronauts' Muscles Age Quickly in Space

results.snippet: A healthy astronaut who spends an extended amount of time at the International Space Station may return to earth with muscles rivaling those of an 80-year-old.
results.lead_paragraph: A young and healthy astronaut who spends six months in the International Space Station is likely to arrive back on earth with the muscles of an 80-year-old, according to a new analysis. The study, paid for by NASA and published in the April issue of The Journal of Applied Physiology, examined nine American and Russian astronauts who had each spent about six months in the station. They had access to various machines for aerobic and resistance exercise, and crew members kept logs of their exercise time.

headline.main: Last Voyage For the Keeper Of the Hubble

results.snippet: For 18 years, one astronaut has tended to the Hubble Space Telescope’s needs. On May 12, John Grunsfeld is scheduled to ride to the telescope’s rescue one last time.

multimedia.caption: The Hubble Repairman
multimedia.credit: John Grunsfeld, a NASA astronaut and scientist, describes his final space mission, scheduled for May 11, to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: John Grunsfeld, a NASA astronaut and scientist, describes his final space mission, scheduled for May 11, to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.

results.lead_paragraph: John Grunsfeld was sitting in an astronomical meeting in Atlanta in January of 2004 when he got a message to come back to headquarters in Washington to talk about the Hubble Space Telescope. To say that he was excited would be an understatement. As an astronaut, Dr. Grunsfeld had twice journeyed to space to make repairs on humanity's most vaunted eye on the cosmos, experiences he had described to a high-level panel pondering Hubble's fate only a few months before as the most meaningful in his life. He was looking forward to leading the third and final servicing mission, which had been delayed by the loss of the shuttle Columbia and its crew the year before.

headline.main: Florida: Ex-Astronaut Wants Some Charges Dismissed

results.snippet: A former astronaut accused of driving 1,000 miles to confront a romantic rival has asked a judge to dismiss some of the charges against her because she claims prosecutors failed to disclose evidence. A lawyer for the ex-astronaut, Lisa Nowak, filed a...
results.lead_paragraph: A former astronaut accused of driving 1,000 miles to confront a romantic rival has asked a judge to dismiss some of the charges against her because she claims prosecutors failed to disclose evidence. A lawyer for the ex-astronaut, Lisa Nowak, filed a motion seeking sanctions against prosecutors and police officers. The motion says they failed to turn over a report that raises questions about whether Ms. Nowak's rival, Colleen Shipman, was pepper-sprayed during the confrontation more than two years ago. Ms. Nowak was charged with attempted kidnapping, burglary and battery with assault. She was dismissed from the astronaut corps after her arrest.

results.snippet: Audio Slide Show: Final Voyage For Hubble's Keeper     Photographs of John Grunsfeld, the astronaut and longtime repairman of the Hubble Space Telescope. In accompanying audio, Mr. Grunsfeld describes preparing for his final ride to the telescope's...
results.lead_paragraph: Audio Slide Show: Final Voyage For Hubble's Keeper Photographs of John Grunsfeld, the astronaut and longtime repairman of the Hubble Space Telescope. In accompanying audio, Mr. Grunsfeld describes preparing for his final ride to the telescope's rescue, scheduled to take place on May 12. This will be the fifth and last time astronauts visit Hubble. At left, Mr. Grunsfeld peers into the crew cabin of the Space Shuttle Columbia during a mission in 2002.

results.lead_paragraph: What we're reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

results.abstract: It's not a node; it's not an elliptical; it's a treadmill.
results.snippet: It's not a node; it's not an elliptical; it's a treadmill.
results.lead_paragraph: In one of those classic compromises cooked up in Washington, NASA announced Tuesday night it had named a treadmill after Stephen Colbert.

results.snippet: An article on April 14 about John Grunsfeld, an astronaut who is scheduled to lead the final servicing mission for the Hubble Space Telescope, referred incorrectly to the capacity of the indoor pool where Dr. Grunsfeld does some training for the...
results.lead_paragraph: An article on April 14 about John Grunsfeld, an astronaut who is scheduled to lead the final servicing mission for the Hubble Space Telescope, referred incorrectly to the capacity of the indoor pool where Dr. Grunsfeld does some training for the mission. The pool holds 6 million gallons, not 11 million. The article also described incorrectly the events leading to his decision to return to the United States after working in Tokyo. Dr. Grunsfeld was living in a Zen monastery, meditating in the morning and then going to work at the University of Tokyo. He came home early one day and found the monks watching baseball on television, breaking the spell of his experience there. He did not find the monks playing baseball.

results.snippet: The market roundup on Wednesday misstated the month of a five-year low in the MSCI index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan. The index bottomed out in November, not March.      An article on April 14 about John Grunsfeld, an astronaut who is...
results.lead_paragraph: The market roundup on Wednesday misstated the month of a five-year low in the MSCI index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan. The index bottomed out in November, not March. An article on April 14 about John Grunsfeld, an astronaut who is scheduled to lead the final servicing mission for the Hubble Space Telescope, referred incorrectly to the capacity of the indoor pool where Dr. Grunsfeld does some training for the mission. The pool holds 6 million gallons, not 11 million. The article also described incorrectly the events leading to his decision to return to the United States after working in Tokyo. Dr. Grunsfeld was living in a Zen monastery, meditating in the morning and then going to work at the University of Tokyo. He came home early one day and found the monks watching baseball on television, breaking the spell of his experience there. He did not find the monks playing baseball.
